input.label: #####There are first a few quick questions about your family background. There are no right or wrong answers. Please select the option that best describes your family.

select1.label: 1. Is the child's natural mother:

input.label: If other European, please state which:

select1.label: 2. Are the grandparents on the mother's side:

input.label: If other European, please state which:

select1.label: 3. Is the child's natural father:

input.label: If other European, please state which:

select1.label: 4. Are the grandparents on the father's side:

input.label: If other European, please state which:

select1.label: 5. Does your daughter participating in the survey currently live with her:

input.label: 6. In addition to you and your daughter, how many people are living in your home?
7. How many brothers and sisters does your daughter have?
8. How many of your daughter's brothers and sisters live at home?
9. How many step or half brothers and sisters does your daughter have?
10. If your daughter has any step brothers or sisters, how many step brothers and sisters live at home?
11. If your daughter has any half brothers or sisters, how many half brothers and sisters live at home?

select.label: 1. Have you completed (please mark all that apply)

input.label: If vocational training, what sort of training was it?

select1.label: 2. Approximate gross family income:
3. What is your current employment status?
4. What is your partner's current employment status?

input.label: 5. If you have paid work, what kind of a job do you do?
6. If your partner has paid work, what kind of a job do they do?

#####Please read each statement carefully and decide how well it describes your own family (who you live with now). You may feel that some of the statements are true for some family members and false for others. If so, please answer according to your best overall impression of your family.
#####This questionnaire relates to the current family environment. Remember there are no right or wrong answers and all information is completely confidential.
#####Please select one for each question.

select1.label: 1. Family members really help and support one another
2. We fight a lot in our family
3. We often seem to be spending time at home
4. Family members rarely become openly angry
5. We put a lot of energy into what we do at home
6. Family members sometimes get so angry they throw things
7. There is a feeling of togetherness in our family
8. Family members hardly ever lose their tempers
9. We rarely volunteer when something has to be done at home
10. Family members often criticise each other
11. Family members really back each other up
12. Family members sometimes hit each other
13. There is very little group spirit in our family
14. If there's a disagreement in our family, we try to smooth things over and keep the peace
15. We really get along well with each other
16. Family members often try to one-up or out-do each other
17. There is plenty of time and attention for everyone in our family
18. In our family, we believe you don't ever get anywhere by raising your voice

input.label:
#####Here are some questions about when you were pregnant with your daughter with a copy number variant
#####Please select the option that best suits you.

select1.label: 1. Was your pregnancy planned?
2. Was the pregnancy with your daughter a multiple birth pregnancy?
3. Did you have fertility treatment?
4. Were you admitted to hospital because of high blood pressure or swollen hands/feet?
5. Did you have any vaginal bleeding during your pregnancy?
6. Did your labour last more than 36 hours?
7. Did your labour last less than 3 hours?
8. Did you have a Caesarean Section?
9. If so, was the Caesarean Section planned?
10. Was your daughter a breech delivery?
11. Did you have a forceps or ventouse delivery?
12. Did your daughter spend any time in SCBU?
13. Did your daughter have to be in an incubator
14. Did you smoke in the year before your pregnancy?
14a. If yes, then how many cigarettes?
15. Did you smoke during your pregnancy?
15a. If yes, then how many cigarettes?
16. Do you smoke now?
16a. If yes, then how many cigarettes?
17. Did you drink alcohol during the year before your pregnancy?
17a. f yes, then how often did you drink alcohol?

item.label: Less than one drink a week
One to six drinks a week
More than six drinks a week

select1.label: 18. Did you drink alcohol during your pregnancy?
18a. If yes, then how often did you drink alcohol?

item.label: Less than one drink a week
One to six drinks a week
More than six drinks a week

select1.label: 19. Was your daughter born:

item.label: On time (40 weeks for single baby, 37 weeks for twins)
A little early (before 40 weeks for single baby, before 37 weeks for twins)
Early (before 37 weeks for single baby, before 34 weeks for twins)
Late (after 40 weeks for single baby, after 37 weeks for twins)

input.label: 20. How old were you when your daughter participating in the study was born?
21. How old was the father when your daughter participating in the study was born?

select1.label: 22. How tall was the daughter in the study at birth?
select1.hint: First select whether to give measurements in imperial or metric

select1.label: 23. How much did the daughter in the study weigh at birth?
select1.hint: First select whether to give measurements in imperial or metric

input.label:
#####We will now ask you questions about the health and development of your daughter with a copy number variant. There are no right or wrong answers.
#####Please select the option that best describes your daughter.

select1.label: 1. How tall is your daughter now?
select1.hint: First select whether to give measurements in imperial or metric

select1.label: 2. How much does your daughter weigh now?
select1.hint: First select whether to give measurements in imperial or metric

input.label: 3. How old was your daughter when she learnt to ride a bike?
4. How old was your daughter when she learnt to do up buttons?
5. How old was your daughter when she learnt to tie shoelaces?

select1.label: 6. Is your daughter clumsy?
7. Did your daughter have failure to thrive in infancy?
8. Did your daughter have feeding difficulties in infancy?
9. Is your daughter behind in reading?
10. Does your daughter have a learning difficulty?
11. Has your daughter been educationally statemented?
12. Was your daughter talking by the age of 2?
13. Did your daughter walk by 18 months of age?
14. Has your daughter ever been admitted overnight to hospital for a head injury?
15. Has your daughter ever had speech therapy?
16. Has your daughter ever had epileptic fits?
17. Was your daughter born with a cleft lip?
18. Was your daughter born with a cleft palate?
19. Does your daughter have frequent ear infections?
20. Does your daughter have frequent infections of the chest/ airways?
21. Does your daughter have any other problems with her airways/ lungs?
22. Does your daughter have other problems with her ears or hearing?
23. Does your daughter have problems with her eyes?
24. Does your daughter have heart problems?
25. Does your daughter have vascular abnormalities (of the veins or arteries)?
26. Does your daughter have thyroid problems?
27. Does your daughter have skeletal or muscular problems?
28. Does your daughter have problems with her abdomen, kidneys or gut?
29. Does your daughter have any other physical health problems?

input.label:
#####The next questions are about changes that may be happening to your daughter's body. These changes normally happen to different young people at different ages and may influence their mood and feelings.
#####Please select the option best describing your daughter. If you do not know the answer, just mark "I don't know."

select1.label: 30. Would you say that your daughter's growth in height:

item.label: Has not yet begun to spurt

select1.label: 31. And how about the growth of your daughter's body hair, such as under her arms? Would you say that her body hair growth:

item.label: Has not yet begun to grow

select1.label: 32. Have you noticed any skin changes in your daughter, especially pimples?

item.label: Skin has not yet started changing

select1.label: 33. Have your daughter's breasts begun to grow?
34. Has your daughter begun to menstruate (started to have her period)?

input.label: 34a. If yes, how old was she when she started to menstruate?
#####Please indicate whether any of the following events have happened in the last 2 years. If you mark 'Yes', you will then be asked to indicate the effect of what happened.

select1.label: 1. Moving to a new neighbourhood
The effect of this event was:
2. Birth of a new brother, sister or adopted or fostered child
The effect of this event was:
3. A new stepbrother or stepsister
The effect of this event was:
4. Changing to a new school
The effect of this event was:
5. Serious illness or injury in a parent, brother or sister
The effect of this event was:
6. Parents divorced or separated
The effect of this event was:
7. Increased quarrelling between parents
The effect of this event was:
8. Death of a parent, brother or sister
The effect of this event was:
9. Death of grandparent
The effect of this event was:
10. Death of a close friend
The effect of this event was:
11. Father/stepfather away from home more often
The effect of this event was:
12. Mother/stepmother away from home more often
The effect of this event was:
13. Brother or sister (or stepbrother/stepsister) leaving home
The effect of this event was:
14. Serious illness or injury in a close friend
The effect of this event was:
15. Parent getting into trouble with the police
The effect of this event was:
16. Mother or stepmother going back to work or starting work for the first time
The effect of this event was:
17. Entry into the home of a new partner for mother or father
The effect of this event was:
18. Parent going to prison
The effect of this event was:
19. Special recognition for good school work
The effect of this event was:
20. Joining a new club
The effect of this event was:
21. Doing badly in an exam
The effect of this event was:
22. Parent being less interested or loving towards this child
The effect of this event was:
23. Parent nagging or picking on this child more often
The effect of this event was:
24. Serious illness or injury to this child
The effect of this event was:
25. Failing to be picked for a school club or team, band or orchestra
The effect of this event was:
26. Doing badly in school work
The effect of this event was:
27. Being picked for a school or club team, band or orchestra
The effect of this event was:
28. Special prize or recognition for doing well in an activity (like sports, music or art)
The effect of this event was:
29. A close friend moves a long way away
The effect of this event was:
30. Losing a close friend through arguments or being dropped
The effect of this event was:
31. Death of a pet
The effect of this event was:
32. Mother losing job
The effect of this event was:
33. Father losing job
The effect of this event was:
34. Bullying by another young person
The effect of this event was:
35. Any event that we have not mentioned but that you think may be important?
The effect of this event was:

input.label:
#####Please read each statement carefully and decide how well it describes your daughter. Remember there are no right or wrong answers and all information is completely confidential.
#####Please select one option for each question, or answer in the space provided when prompted.

select1.label: 1. Did your daughter ever have a seizure or convulsion caused by a high fever?
2. Other than the seizures associated with high fevers, has your daughter ever had a seizure, convulsion, fit, or spell - under any circumstances
2a. Roughly how frequently does/ did this occur?
2b. Do/ did these occur:

item.label: Both during the day and night

select1.label: 2c. When was the most recent occurrence?
3. Other than the seizures associated with high fevers, has your daughter ever had uncontrolled movements of part or all of his body such as twitching, jerking, shaking or going limp?
3a. Roughly how frequently does/ did this occur?
3b. Do/ did these occur:

item.label: Both during the day and night

select1.label: 4. Other than the seizures associated with high fevers, has your daughter ever had an unexplained change in his mental state or level of awareness; or an episode of 'spacing out' that he could not control?
5. Does your daughter daydream or stare into space more than other children?
6. Have you ever noticed her to have any unusual body movements when exposed to strobe lights, video games, flickering lights, or sun glare?

7. Shortly after waking up, either in the morning or after a nap, have you ever noticed your daughter have uncontrollable jerking or clumsiness, such as dropping things or things suddenly flying from her hands?
8. Has your daughter ever had any other type of repeated unusual spells?
9. Has your daughter ever been diagnosed with a seizure disorder or epilepsy?

input.label: 9a. At what age did your daughter receive this diagnosis?

select1.label: 9b. Has your daughter ever been prescribed medication to control his seizures/ epilepsy?
9d. Was the medication effective?

input.label:
#####Please think about the times during the past 3 months when you and your daughter have spent time talking or doing things together.
#####With those times in mind, please cross the box which tells how often you acted in the following ways towards your daughter during the past 3 months.
#####During the past 3 months, how often did you

select1.label: 36. Get angry at her
37. Let her know you really care about her
38. Criticise her
39. Shout at her because you were upset with her
40. Act loving and affectionate towards her
41. Let her know that you appreciate her ideas or the things she does
42. Help her do something that was important to her
43. Argue with her when you disagreed about something
44. Act supportive and understanding toward her
45. Tell her you love her

input.label:
#####For each item, please mark the box that best describes your daughter. It would help us if you answered all items as best you can, even if you are not absolutely certain or the item seems daft!
#####Please give your answers on the basis of the daughter's behaviour over the last six months or this school year.

select1.label: 1. Considerate of other people's feelings
2. Restless, overactive, cannot stay still for long
3. Often complains of headaches, stomach-aches or sickness
4. Shares readily with other children (treats, toys, pencils etc.)
5. Often has temper tantrums or hot tampers
6. Rather solitary, tends to play alone
7. Generally obedient, usually does what adults request
8. Many worries, often seems worried
9. Helpful if someone is hurt, upset or feeling ill
10. Constantly fidgeting or squirming
11. Has at least one good friend
12. Frequently fights or is extremely quarrelsome with other children
13. Bullies other children
14. Often unhappy, down-hearted or tearful
15. Generally liked by other children
16. Easily distracted, concentration wanders
17. Nervous or clingy in new situations, easily loses confidence
18. Kind to younger children
19. Often tells lies
20. Often cheats
21. Picked on or bullied by other children
22. Often volunteers to help others (parents, teachers, other children)
23. Steals from home, school or elsewhere
24. If true, has your daughter stolen more than once in the past 12 months?
25. Gets on better with adults than with other children
26. Many fears, easily scared
27. Blames others for things
28. Hits or kicks other children
29. Inconsiderate of others

input.label: If you have answered 'somewhat true' or 'certainly true' to any of the questions above please complete the following.
Overall, do you think that they have difficulties in one or more of the following areas: Emotions, concentration, behaviour or being able to get on with other people?

select1.label: Difficulties with their emotions
Difficulties with their concentration
Difficulties with being able to get on with people

input.label: If you have answered "Yes" to any of the above, please answer the following questions about these difficulties.
1. How long have these difficulties been present?

select1.label: Difficulties with their emotions
Difficulties with their concentration
Difficulties with being able to get on with people
2. Do the difficulties upset or distress them?

input.label: 3. Do the difficulties interfere with their everyday life in the following areas?

select1.label: HOME LIFE
FRIENDSHIPS
CLASSROOM LEARNING
LEISURE ACTIVITIES
4. Do the difficulties make it harder for those around them (family, friends, teachers, etc.)?

input.label: ###9. Your daughter's behaviour and social communication

#####A few questions ask about several related types of behaviour. Please tick the appropriate box if any one of these behaviours was present.
#####Although you may be uncertain about whether some behaviours were present or not, please put a cross in the box that best describes your daughter for every question on the basis of what you think.

select1.label: 1. Is she able to talk using short phrases or sentences?
select1.hint: If 'no', you will skip to question 9

select1.label: 2. Does she ever talk with you just to be friendly (rather than to get something)?
3. Can you now have a to and fro "conversation" with her that involves taking turns or building on what you said?
4. Has she ever used odd phrases or said the same thing over and over in almost exactly the same way? That is, either phrases she has heard other people use or ones she has made up.
5. Has she ever used socially inappropriate questions or statements? For example, has she ever regularly asked personal questions or made personal comments at awkward times?
6. Does she ever get her pronouns the wrong way round, i.e. saying 'you' or 'she' for I?
7. Has she ever used words that she seems to have invented or made up herself or ever put things in odd indirect ways or metaphorical ways of saying things? For example, saying hot rain for steam?
8. Has she ever said the same thing over and over in exactly the same way, or insist on you saying the same things over and over again?
9. Has she ever had things that she seemed to have to do in a very particular way or order, or rituals that she has to have you do?
10. Does her facial expression usually seem appropriate to the particular situation, as far as you can tell?
11. Has she ever used your hand like a tool or as if it were part of her own body (e.g. pointing with your finger, putting your hand on a doorknob to get you to open the door)?
12. Has she ever had any interests that pre-occupy her and might seem odd to other people (e.g. traffic lights, drain pipes or timetables)?
13. Has she ever seemed to be more interested in a certain part of a toy (e.g. spinning the wheels of a car) or an object rather than using the object as it was intended?
14. Has she ever had any special interests that were unusual in their intensity but otherwise appropriate for her age and peer group (e.g. trains, dinosaurs)?
15. Has she ever seemed to be unusually interested in the sight, sound, taste or smell of things or people?
16. Has she ever had any mannerisms or odd ways of moving her hands or fingers, such as flapping, or moving her fingers in front of her eyes?
17. Has she ever had any complicated movement of her whole body, such as spinning or repeatedly bouncing up and down?
18. Does she ever injure herself deliberately, such as hitting herself, biting her arm or banging her head?
19. Does she have any objects (other than a soft toy or comfort blanket) that she has to carry around with her?
20. Does she have any particular friends or a best friend?

input.label: #####For some behaviours, it is most helpful to focus on the time period between 4th birthday and 5th birthday. You may find it easier to remember how things were at that time by fixing in your mind in relation to key happenings such as starting school, moving house, Christmas time, or any other events that are particularly memorable for you as a family.

select1.label: 21. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever spontaneously copy you (or other people), or what you were doing (such as hoovering, gardening, mending things)?
22. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever spontaneously point at things around her just to show you things (not because she wanted them)?
23. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever use gestures, other than pointing or pulling your hand, to let you know what she wanted?
24. When she was 4 to 5 did she nod her head to mean "yes"?
25. When she was 4 to 5 did she shake her head to mean "no"?
26. When she was 4 to 5 did she usually look you directly in the face when doing things with you or talking with you?
27. When she was 4 to 5 did she smile back if someone smiled at her?
28. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever show you things that interested her to engage your attention?
29. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever offer to share things other than food with you?
30. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever seem to want you to join in her enjoyment of something?
31. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever try to comfort you if you were sad or hurt?
32. Between the ages of 4 to 5 when she wanted something or wanted help, did she used to look at you and use gestures with sounds or words to get your attention?
33. Between the ages of 4 to 5 did she show a normal range of facial expression?
34. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever spontaneously join in and try to copy actions in social games such as The Mulberry Bush or The Farmer's in his Den?
35. When she was 4 to 5 did she play any pretend or make believe games?
36. When she was 4 to 5 did she seem interested in other children of approximately the same age whom she did not know?
37. When she was 4 to 5 did she respond positively when another child approached her?
38. When she was 4 to 5 if you came into a room and started talking to her without calling her name, did she usually look up and pay attention to you?
39. When she was 4 to 5 did she ever play imaginative games with another child in such a way that you could tell they understood what each other was pretending?
40. When she was 4 to 5 did she play co-operatively in games that need some form of joining in with a group of other children, such as hide and seek or ball games?

input.label:
#####Many of the following behaviours may not apply to your daughter. For each item that does describe your daughter, now or within the past six months, please mark the box for not true, somewhat true or certainly true.
#####If your daughter is unable to perform an item, please mark the box 'not true'. For example, if your daughter has no speech, then for the item "Talks too much or too fast" tick the box with 'not true'.

select1.label: 1. Appears depressed, downcast or unhappy.
2. Avoids eye contact. Won't look you straight in the eye.
3. Aloof, in her own world.
4. Abusive. Swears at others.
5. Arranges objects or routine in a strict order.
6. Bangs head.
7. Becomes over-excited.
8. Bites others.
9. Cannot attend to one activity for any length of time, poor attention span.
10. Chews or mouths objects, or body parts.
11. Cries easily for no reason, or over small upsets.
12. Covers ears or is distressed when hears particular sounds.
13. Deliberately runs away.
14. Delusions: has a firmly held belief or idea that can't possibly be true
15. Distressed about being alone.
16. Doesn't show affection.
17. Doesn't respond to others' feelings, e.g. shows no response if a family member is crying.
18. Easily distracted from her task, e.g. by noises.
19. Easily led by others.
20. Eats non-food items, e.g. dirt, grass, soap.
21. Excessively distressed if separated from familiar person.
22. Fears particular things or situations, e.g. the dark or insects.
23. Facial twitches or grimaces.
24. Flicks, taps, twirls objects repeatedly.
25. Fussy eater or has food fads.
26. Gorges food. Will do anything to get food, e.g. takes food out of garbage bins or steals food.
27. Gets obsessed with an idea or activity.
28. Grinds teeth.
29. Has nightmares, night terrors or walks in sleep.
30. Has temper tantrums, e.g. stamps feet, slams doors.
31. Hides things.
32. Hums, whines, grunts, squeals or makes other non-speech noises.
33. Impatient.
34. Impulsive, acts before thinking.
35. Irritable.
36. Jealous.
37. Lacks self-confidence, poor self-esteem.
38. Laughs or giggles for no obvious reason.
39. Lights fires.
40. Likes to hold or play with an unusual object, e.g. string, twigs; overly fascinated with something, e.g. water.
41. Loss of appetite.
42. Mood changes rapidly for no apparent reason.
43. Moves slowly, underactive, does little, e.g. only sits and watches others.
44. Noisy or boisterous.
45. Overaffectionate.
46. Overbreathes, vomits, has headaches or complains of being sick for no physical reason.
47. Overly attention-seeking.
48. Overly interested in looking at, listening to or dismantling mechanical things e.g. lawnmower, vacuum cleaner
49. Poor sense of danger.
50. Prefers the company of adults or younger children. Doesn't mix with her own age group.
51. Prefers to do things on her own. Tends to be a loner.
52. Preoccupied with only one or two particular interests.
53. Refuses to go to school or activity centre.
54. Repeated movements of hands, body, head or face, e.g. handflapping or rocking.
55. Resists being cuddled, touched or held.
56. Repeats back what others say like an echo.
57. Repeats the same word or phrase over and over.
58. Smells, tastes, or licks objects.
59. Scratches or picks her skin.
60. Screams a lot.
61. Sleeps too little. Disrupted sleep.
62. Stares at lights or spinning objects.
63. Sleeps too much.
64. Soils outside toilet though toilet trained. Smears or plays with faeces.
65. Speaks in whispers, high pitched voice, or other unusual tone or rhythm.
66. Switches lights on and off, pours water over and over; or similar repetitive activity.
67. Stubborn, disobedient or uncooperative.
68. Shy.
69. Strips off clothes or throws away clothes.
70. Says she can do things that she is not capable of.
71. Stands too close to others.
72. Sees, hears, something which isn't there. Hallucinations.
73. Talks about suicide.
74. Talks too much or too fast.
75. Talks to self or imaginary people or objects.
76. Tells lies.
77. Thoughts are unconnected. Different ideas are jumbled together with meaning difficult to follow.
78. Tense, anxious, worried.
79. Throws or breaks objects
80. Tries to manipulate or provoke others.
81. Under reacts to pain.
82. Unrealistically happy or elated.
83. Unusual body movements, posture, or way of walking.
84. Upset and distressed over small changes in routine or environment.
85. Urinates outside toilet, although toilet trained.
86. Very bossy.
87. Wanders aimlessly.
88. Whines or complains a lot.

input.label: 89. Please write in any problems your daughter has that were not listed above.

select1.label: 90. Overall, do you feel your daughter has problems with feelings or behaviour, in addition to problems with development? If not, please cross the box for 'not true'. If so, but they are minor, cross the box for 'somewhat true'. If they're major problems, cross the box for 'certainly true'.

input.label: ###11. Your daughter's coordination and motor development

#####This section asks about motor skills, things that your daughter does with her hands, or when moving. A child's coordination may improve each year as they grow and develop. For this reason, when answering the questions it is best to think about other children you know who are the same age as your daughter.
#####Please read the following questions and tick the box that is the most appropriate for your daughter's coordination

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 1. Your daughter throws a ball in a controlled and accurate fashion

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 2. Your daughter catches a small ball (e.g. tennis ball size) thrown from a distance of 6-8 feet (1.8-2.4 metres)

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 3. Your daughter hits an approaching ball with a bat or racquet accurately

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 4. Your daughter jumps easily over obstacles found in a garden or play environment

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 5. Your daughter runs as fast and in a similar way to other children of the same age and gender

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 6. If your daughter has a plan to do a motor activity, she can organise her body to follow the plan and effectively complete the task (e.g., building a cardboard or cushion 'fort', moving on playground equipment, building a house or a structure with blocks, or using craft materials

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 7. Your daughter's printing or writing or drawing in class is fast enough to keep up with the rest of the children in her class

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 8. Your daughter's printing or writing letters, numbers and words is legible, precise, and accurate or, if your daughter is not yet printing, she colours and draws in a coordinated way and makes pictures you recognise

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 9. Your daughter uses appropriate effort or tension when printing or writing or drawing (no excessive pressure or tightness of grasp on the pencil, writing is not too heavy or dark, or too light.

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 10. Your daughter cuts pictures and shapes accurately

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 11. Your daughter is interested in, and likes participating in sports or active games requiring good motor skills

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 12. Your daughter learns new motor tasks (e.g., swimming, rollerblading) easily and does not require more practice or time than other children to achieve the same level of skill.

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 13. Your daughter is quick and competent in tidying up, putting on shoes, tying shoes, dressing etc.

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 14. Your daughter would never be described as a 'bull in a china shop' (that is, appears so clumsy that they might break fragile things in a small room)

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

select1.label: 15. Your daughter does not fatigue easily or appear to slouch and 'fall out' of her chair if she's required to sit for long periods

item.label: Not at all like your child
Quite a bit like your child

input.label:
#####For each item, please mark the box that best describes your daughter's relationship to food and their food related behaviour. It would help us if you answered all items as best you can, even if you are not absolutely certain or the item seems daft!
#####Please read the following statements and tick the boxes most appropriate to your daughter's relationship to food

select1.label: 1. My child loves food
2. My child eats more when worried
3. My child has a big appetite
4. My child finishes her meal quickly
5. My child is interested in food
6. My child is always asking for a drink
7. My child refuses new foods at first
8. My child eats slowly
9. My child eats less when angry
10. My child enjoys tasting new foods
11. My child eats less when she is tired
12. My child is always asking for food
13. My child eats more when annoyed
14. If allowed to, my child would eat too much
15. My child eats more when anxious
16. My child enjoys a wide variety of foods
17. My child leaves food on her plate at the end of a meal
18. My child takes more than 30 minutes to finish a meal
19. Given the choice, my child would eat most of the time
20. My child looks forward to mealtimes
21. My child gets full before her meal is finished
22. My child enjoys eating
23. My child eats more when she is happy
24. My child is difficult to please with meals
25. My child eats less when upset
26. My child gets full up easily
27. My child eats more when she has nothing else to do
28. Even if my child is full up she finds room to eat his/her favourite food
29. If given the chance, my child would drink continuously throughout the day
30. My child cannot eat a meal if she has had a snack just before
31. If given the chance, my child would always be having a drink
32. My child is interested in tasting food she hasn't tasted before
33. My child decides that she doesn't like a food, even without tasting it
34. If given the chance, my child would always have food in her mouth
35. My child eats more and more slowly during the course of a meal
36. How upset does your child generally become when denied a desired food?
37. How often does your child try to bargain or manipulate to get more food at mealtimes?
38. Once your child has food on their mind, how easy is it for you or others to re-direct your child away from food to other things?

item.label: Extremely easy, takes minimal effort to do so
Very easy, takes just a little effort to do so
Somewhat hard, takes some effort to do so
Very hard, takes a lot of work to do so
Extremely hard, takes sustained and hard work to do so

select1.label: 39. How often does your child forage through the trash for food?
40. How often does your child get up at night to food seek?
41. How persistent is your child in asking or looking for food after being told "no" or "no more"?

item.label: Lets go of food ideas quickly and easily
Lets go of food ideas pretty quickly and easily

select1.label: 42. Outside of normal meal times, how much time does your child spend talking about food or engaged in food-related behaviours?

item.label: 30 minutes to an hour a day

select1.label: 43. How often does your child try to steal food (that you are aware of)?
44. When others try to stop your child from talking about food or engaging in food-related behaviours, it generally leads to:

item.label: Extreme distress, behaviours can't usually be stopped

select1.label: 45. How clever or fast is your child in obtaining food?
46. To what extent do food-related thoughts, talk or behaviour interfere with your child's normal daily routines, self-care, school or work?

item.label: Mild interference; occasional food-related interference in completing school, work or hygiene tasks
Moderate interference; frequent food-related interference in completing school, work or hygiene tasks
Severe interference; almost daily food-related interference in completing school, work or hygiene tasks
Extreme interference; often unable to participate in hygiene tasks or to get to school or work due to food-related difficulties

input.label: 47. How old was your child when they first showed an increased interest in food?

select1.label: 48. How variable is your child's preoccupation or interest in food?

item.label: Goes up and down quite a lot
Goes up and down all the time

input.label:
#####Thank you for filling in the questions so far. On this final page, we will ask a few questions on your experience in filling in the questionnaire
#####What did you think of this questionnaire? Your participation has been vital to the success of this study. As a final request, we would be very grateful for any feedback you may have relating to this questionnaire. If you need any more space to answer any of the questions, please continue writing on the blank sheets at the back of the booklet.

select1.label: 1. Overall, how relevant have you found the focus of this questionnaire to your family?
2. How useful have you found it to reflect on the questions asked?
3. Were there any questions that you particularly enjoyed answering?

input.label: 4. If yes, please describe which question(s) and why

select1.label: 5. Were there any questions that you particularly did not enjoy answering or had difficulty answering?

input.label: 6. If yes, please describe which question(s) and why

#####Thank you very much for completing this questionnaire!
#####Remember, if you have found any aspects of this questionnaire difficult to answer and feel the need for support, please refer to the contact numbers given on the information sheet.
